comments:
Since I started using M7 (previously I was using M5) Eclipse has been exiting
periodically (once every few days) whilst I am using it with no obvious pattern
other than it seems to mostly happen just after I cause a window (e.g a dialog
box) to open. It exits cleanly and saves the workspace each time. I'm unable to
reproduce this behavior on-demand unfortunately.

I wonder if eclipse is leaking handles? Or does M7 just require more than M5?

Here are some of the stack traces. Each one is follwed in the log by an
"Unhandled event loop exception" with no stack trace.

Here is my session info:

Sorry, Bugzilla swallowed the comment I wrote while posting my eclipse config.

oXygen, Subclipse and JSEdit (org.hkataria). I've been using -Xmx500M, will now
start trying -Xmx600M. When this happens, Eclipse crashes, sometimes asking me
if I want to end the workbench, but usually just bringing the VM error dialog
box. This is happening several times a week. Here's the stack trace from the
most recent occurrence (repeats several times):

cc'ing DP and PW as they are using Linux not sure if they've seen this.

BB, note: no more handles on GTK.  Not sure how this can happen.  Windows has 
a fixed number of handles that is unrelated to memory.  You can still have 
memory but no more handles.  Linux just keeps allocating.  Thoughts?

We use ERROR_NO_HANDLES in SWT/GTK+ when we often mean out of memory.  In this
case, gdk_gc_new() is returning NULL, which only happens if malloc() fails.

John, while both your problem and Tim's seem similar, both a memory and resource
leak, there are some key differences: Linux vs Windows, and lots of plugins vs
no additional plugins.  John, could you file a new bug report?  Tim, are you
still experiencing this leak?

However, in both cases I think the way to proceed is similar.  Since we haven't
found these leaks here, it must be something about the workflow in each case
which is causing the leak.  John, since it seems we're running out of memory for
you, can you watch Eclipse with 'top' or 'xrestop' and see if you can see
anything in particular that causes a large spike in memory usage?  If possible,
removing some of the plugins you are using and seeing if the problem gets better
might narrow down where the leak is occuring.

Tim, can you watch the Eclipse memory usage and handle counts in the Windows
system monitor thing and see if that can help narrow down the trigger?

This happened multiple times when I was using 3.1M7, but I haven't experienced
it with any other builds (previous or subsequent) that I have used. I didn't see
it in any of the 3.1RC builds, and I haven't seen it in 3.1 either.

I did do two seperate installs of M7 and saw it in both. I guess whatever was
causing it was related to the configuration of my machine at the time, or
specific to M7 (or both).

OK, I'm closing this as WORKSFORME then.  John: Please file a new bug report
with your log, and see comment #9.
